questions.text: A 6-year-old child from northern part of Russia is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of pain in the legs and difficulty walking. As they were in their tour to Goa, they wanted to treat their child as early as possible and need to return to their country before their visa expires. On taking history, the child has been exclusively breastfed and does not receive any sunlight exposure due to climatic conditions over there. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the history of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickets.

 

Option B:

 

Rickets is a disease of growing bone that occurs in children due to vitamin D deficiency, which is essential for calcium absorption. The child's lack of sunlight exposure, which is necessary for the skin to synthesize vitamin D, especially when living in high latitudes with limited sun exposure, is a key risk factor for rickets. Breast milk alone without vitamin D supplementation can also be a contributing factor, as it may not provide adequate vitamin D levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scurvy: Caused by vitamin C deficiency, scurvy presents with symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and anemia, but it does not typically cause bone pain or issues related to bone growth.

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density and brittle bones. While it can cause bone pain, it is not related to sunlight exposure or dietary intake.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: While juvenile rheumatoid arthritis can cause joint pain and difficulty walking, it is less likely in this scenario without other systemic symptoms and given the specific context of the child's history with sunlight exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lack of exposure to sunlight and exclusive breastfeeding can lead to vitamin D deficiency, causing rickets in children. The radiological image shows cupping, splaying and fraying of the metaphysis typically seen in case of rickets.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 336- 340.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department in a collapsed state after experiencing 12 episodes of vomiting. On examination, he is found to have a feeble pulse and cold, clammy limbs. An emergency ECG reveals significant abnormalities. Which electrolyte imbalance is most likely responsible for the findings observed in this patient's ECG?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

 

Option B:

 

ECG shows classical ‘sine wave pattern’ which is seen in case of hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia, an elevated level of potassium in the blood, can significantly affect cardiac conduction and the electrical activity of the heart, leading to characteristic changes on an electrocardiogram (ECG). In severe cases, it can cause life-threatening cardiac dysrhythmias. The symptoms of collapse, vomiting (which can contribute to electrolyte imbalances), feeble pulse, and cold, clammy limbs in this patient, coupled with the ECG findings, suggest hyperkalemia as the most likely cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia results in the ECG findings of Prolonged PR interval, Reduction in T wave amplitude / flattening / inversion, ST depression and Appearance of U wave.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia results in the ECG findings of Prolonged QTs segment (secondary to lengthening of ST segment).

 

Option D. Hypomagnesemia results in the ECG findings of ST segment depression, Flat T waves or depression in the precordium, U waves and PR prolongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 8th Edition, Page No-76.

choices.text: 77 mEq of sodium in 1000 mL of fluid
130 mEq of sodium in 1000 mL of fluid
513 mEq of sodium in 1000 mL of fluid
26 mEq of sodium in 1000 mL of fluid

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after being rescued from a house fire. The child has sustained second-degree burns over 15% of their body surface area. The medical team decides to initiate fluid resuscitation as part of the initial management. Considering the need for an isotonic solution to restore intravascular volume, which of the following solutions would be most appropriate for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 130 mEq of sodium in 1000 mL of fluid.

 

Explanation:

 

The solution containing 130 mEq of sodium per 1000 mL of fluid is Ringer's lactate, which is an isotonic solution often used in fluid resuscitation for burn patients. It contains electrolytes closely resembling those of the body's plasma, making it suitable for restoring intravascular volume without causing significant shifts in electrolyte balance.

 

The sodium concentration of RL is 130 mEq.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-289

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the pediatric clinic with her child, who has experienced 7 episodes of loose stools from morning till evening. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes mild dehydration in the child. Considering the clinical presentation and the need for rehydration, which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid choice for managing diarrhea in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ORS

 

Option C:

 

The initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is ORS. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestines, effectively replacing lost fluids and electrolytes. Its composition aligns with the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for rehydration, making it highly effective in preventing and treating dehydration from diarrhea in children.

 

The cornerstone of acute diarrhea management is rehydration by using oral rehydration solutions (ORS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Salt Water: While rehydration requires salt, salt water alone is not recommended due to its high sodium concentration, which can worsen dehydration and lead to hypernatremia.

 

Option B. Sugar Water: Sugar water can provide some energy but lacks the necessary electrolytes needed to correct the electrolyte imbalances caused by diarrhea. It is not sufficient for rehydration purposes.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Normal Saline is an intravenous solution that can be used in more severe cases of dehydration or when oral rehydration is not possible. However, for mild dehydration and when oral intake is feasible, ORS is preferred due to its ease of use and effectiveness in promoting intestinal water and electrolyte absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestine.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-289.

questions.text: You are reviewing a newborn in the neonatal unit who was delivered 2 hours ago to a mother with a history of diabetes. The infant's initial blood glucose measurement is 60 mg/dl. Considering the maternal history of diabetes and the current blood glucose level of the infant, which of the following additional tests is most appropriate to order next for this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum calcium

 

Option C:

 

In the context of an infant born to a diabetic mother, the risk for certain metabolic abnormalities, including hypocalcemia, is elevated. The infant's initial blood glucose level of 60 mg/dl, while within a normal range, prompts further investigation due to the maternal diabetes history. Hypocalcemia is a common complication in infants of diabetic mothers, and early detection and management are crucial to prevent associated risks such as tetany, seizures, and arrhythmias. Therefore, assessing serum calcium levels is a critical next step in the care of this newborn.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serum Potassium: While important in assessing overall electrolyte balance, potassium levels are not the immediate concern in the context of an infant of a diabetic mother without any specific symptoms of hyperkalemia or hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Complete Blood Count (CBC): A CBC can provide valuable information about an infant's hematologic status but is not the most relevant test for a newborn of a diabetic mother in the absence of clinical signs suggestive of infection, anemia, or polycythemia.

 

Option D. Serum Chloride: Serum chloride levels, though part of the electrolyte panel, are not specifically indicated in this scenario. The focus is on the more common metabolic derangements associated with infants of diabetic mothers, such as hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of a diabetic mother are at a higher risk of metabolic complications as complications to normal infants.
  • These complications include:
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hence the infant needs to be checked for these as soon as possible.
  • Therefore, the correct options will be Serum Calcium levels.

 

Ref: nelson 21st edition page 4206

questions.text: A 17-month-old child is brought to a pediatric clinic in India for a routine eye examination. The examining physician notes a thinned-out cornea during the assessment. Further history reveals that the child has been diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. The child's current weight is recorded at 10 kg. Considering the child's age and clinical findings suggestive of vitamin A deficiency, what is the appropriate dose of vitamin A supplementation for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2,00,000 IU

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features mentioned in this are suggestive of keratomalacia and the dose of vitamin A given in this child of 17 months is 2,00,000 IU.

 

 

keratomalacia

 

Vitamin A deficiency is characterized by night blindness and conjunctival xerosis. Bitot’s spots, Keratomalacia and fundus changes in severe cases.

 

Clouding of cornea in a child with Vit A deficiency is emergency → requires parenteral administration of 50,000 -100,000 IU Retinol

 

  • In keratomalacia → Local treatment with antibiotic drops & ointment, padding of eye → enhances healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Vitamin A deficiency:

 

<6 months of age Vitamin A 50,000 IU orally/dose

6-12 months of age Vitamin A 100,000 IU orally/dose

≥12 months of age Vitamin A 2,00,000 1U orally/dose

The same dose is repeated next day & weeks later.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 118.

choices.text: 1 Lakh IU
2 Lakh IU
2.5 lakh IU

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric clinic for a routine health check-up. The child appears well-nourished and is meeting developmental milestones appropriately. The pediatrician decides to administer a prophylactic dose of vitamin A as part of the National Program for the Prevention of Nutritional Blindness. Considering the child's age and the national guidelines, what is the appropriate dose of vitamin A to be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)1 Lakh IU

 

Explanation:

 

For infants aged 9 completed months, the recommended prophylactic vitamin A dose is 100,000 IU. This initiative aims to reduce the risk of vitamin A deficiency, which can lead to xerophthalmia and an increased susceptibility to infections, contributing to child morbidity and mortality.

 

Educational objective:

 

As per, NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

 

9 completed months – 1 Lakh IU;

 

Every 6 months: 2 Lac IU (each dose) till 5 years’ age of the child.

 

(In, total 17 Lac IU is given to a completely immunized child by 5 years of age)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 1926

choices.text: Copper deficiency and 10 mg
Zinc deficiency and 20 mg
Copper deficiency and 20 mg
Zinc deficiency and 10 mg

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluates a 3-month-old infant brought in by the mother due to recurrent infections, persistent diarrhea, and notable skin lesions. Considering the clinical presentation, as shown in the images, which micronutrient deficiency is most commonly associated with these symptoms, and what is the recommended starting dosage for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc deficiency and 10 mg.

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of Acrodermatitis enteropathica, a rare genetic disorder resulting from the impaired absorption and metabolism of zinc, leading to its deficiency. This condition is characterized by dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea. The skin findings typically present around the body orifices and extremities, as shown in the image. The recommended treatment is zinc supplementation, which is usually given at a dose of 10 mg per day for <6 months’ infants.

 

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica (AE)

 

  • Autosomal recessive trait (Defect in SLC39A4 - encode hZIP4 protein)
  • 5D’s Dermatological changes, Diarrhea, Developmental impairment, Depression & death

 

Diagnosis & Treatment of Zinc deficiency

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dosage of Zinc for diarrhea:

 

<6 months of age – 10 mg/day.

>6 months of age – 20 mg/day.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
Vitamin D deficiency

questions.text:
A 1-year-old infant is seen in a clinic in India with a history of difficulty walking and frequent falls. The infant was exclusively breastfed for the first six months and has had a diet primarily consisting of milk and cereal since then. According to the mother, the child has limited outdoor activities and is always fully covered when outside. Physical examination reveals bowed legs and tenderness in the lower limbs. An X-ray of the legs is performed, showing the characteristic changes as depicted in the provided radiograph.

 

 

Based on the clinical history and the radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Option B:

 

The child's presentation is highly suggestive of rickets, a vitamin D deficiency disorder. The child's presentation with difficulty walking, frequent falls, bowed legs, tenderness on palpation of the lower limbs, and radiographic findings of a frayed and widened epiphyseal growth plate, cupping and flaring of the metaphysis, and thinning of the cortex is highly suggestive of rickets, a vitamin D deficiency disorder that leads to inadequate mineralization of the growing bones.

 

Breast milk and milk-based foods are poor sources of vitamin D, and limited sun exposure can also contribute to vitamin D deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia may cause fatigue and pallor but is not associated with difficulty walking and radiographic findings of rickets, which are present in this case.

 

Option C. Calcium deficiency: Calcium deficiency can lead to weakened bones, but it is not typically associated with the radiographic findings of rickets.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemic rickets: Hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that affects the renal phosphate reabsorption and is associated with decreased serum phosphate levels, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray finding of rickets - widening, fraying, and irregularity of the metaphyses, commonly seen in the wrist and knee joints.

 

The risk factors for vitamin D deficiency, including exclusive breastfeeding without supplementation, lack of sunlight exposure, and protective clothing practices that limit skin exposure to sunlight. Early recognition and treatment with vitamin D supplementation can prevent progression and complications associated with this condition.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page NO- 336- 340.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
Vitamin D deficiency
Vitamin C deficiency
Folate deficiency anemia

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to a healthcare facility with a presenting complaint of lethargy, irritability, and bleeding gums noted during tooth brushing. The dietary history taken from the parents reveals a restricted diet predominantly composed of carbohydrates and fats, with an absence of fresh fruits and vegetables for several months. On physical examination, the child has multiple petechiae and ecchymoses scattered across the skin. The gums are swollen, tender, and bleed upon slight manipulation. Laboratory tests show a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL. Based on the child's clinical presentation and nutritional history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C deficiency

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation suggests scurvy, which is caused by vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency. Vitamin C is a vital nutrient that plays a role in the synthesis of collagen, and its deficiency leads to symptoms like lethargy, irritability, spongy gums, and bleeding due to fragile blood vessels, as well as poor wound healing. The dietary history of a lack of fresh fruits and vegetables supports this diagnosis since these are primary sources of vitamin C.

 

Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, which is important for the structural integrity of blood vessels, bone, and connective tissue. Scurvy is a rare condition in developed countries due to widespread availability of fresh fruits and vegetables.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: While the child's hemoglobin level is low, the symptoms of lethargy and irritability could be consistent with anemia; however, the bleeding gums and skin findings are more specific to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency: This typically presents with bone-related symptoms and signs such as rickets, muscle weakness, or pain and does not usually cause bleeding disorders or anemia.

 

Option D. Folate deficiency anemia: Although folate deficiency can lead to anemia, it is not typically associated with bleeding gums or skin petechiae, which are indicative of a problem with blood vessel integrity or platelet function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-329-331

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns about delayed dentition and poor growth. The child's diet is noted to be low in dairy products and vegetables. On physical examination, the boy is shorter than his peers, and his dentition is notably delayed. A wrist X-ray is performed, findings shown below.

 

 

Based on the clinical features and radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rickets

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation of delayed dentition, retarded growth, and dietary deficiency, along with the characteristic radiographic findings of metaphyseal widening, fraying, and cupping of the wrist, are highly suggestive of rickets. Rickets is a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired mineralization of bone and cartilage. In children, this can result in skeletal deformities, delayed growth, and dental issues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: This condition is characterized by bone fragility and is typically diagnosed based on a history of frequent fractures and blue sclerae. Radiographs would show thin bones with multiple fracture sites, not the findings seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Scurvy: Caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, scurvy can lead to swollen, bleeding gums and bruising, but the radiographic signs would show 'scorbutic rosaries' at the costochondral junctions, not the metaphyseal changes seen in rickets.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder leading to abnormally dense bones, with radiographs showing increased bone density and bone within a bone appearance, which does not match the findings in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential Diagnosis – based on Radiological findings

 

Rickets - Cupping and fraying of the metaphyses.

 

Osteogenesis Imperfecta - Thin bones with multiple fracture

 

Scurvy - 'Scorbutic rosaries' at the costochondral junctions

 

Osteopetrosis - Increased bone density and bone within a bone appearance

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page NO- 336- 340.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of fatigue, weakness, easy bruisability, and bleeding gums. The parents report a dietary history that is heavily reliant on junk food, with a notable absence of fresh fruits and vegetables. An X-ray of the child’s legs shows changes suggestive of a nutritional deficiency. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scurvy

 

Option A:

 

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is necessary for the synthesis of collagen. The child’s symptoms of fatigue, weakness, easy bruisability, and bleeding gums are classic signs of scurvy, and a diet lacking in fresh fruits and vegetables would lead to such a deficiency. The X-ray would show subperiosteal hemorrhages and cortical thinning, which are radiographic signs consistent with scurvy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rickets: This condition is related to vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate deficiency and would more commonly present with bone pain and skeletal deformities, not the soft tissue and vascular symptoms seen in scurvy.

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis: Also known as 'marble bone disease', osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth but does not cause easy bruising or gum bleeding.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: This autoimmune condition is rare in this age group and would typically present with joint swelling and pain, rather than bleeding and dietary deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy (d/to vitamin C deficiency) -  Radiological features include Wimberger’s ring, White line of Frankel and Pelkan’s spur.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-329-331

questions.text: During a family trip to Manali, a 10-month-old child is involved in a severe car accident, sustaining a head injury with significant bleeding after colliding with the rear-view mirror. Upon examination, the child exhibits cold extremities and an elevated pulse rate. Given the clinical scenario, what type of shock is most commonly expected in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypovolemic shock

 

Option B:

 

Based on the history given, the most common shock to be expected in a bleeding child with cold extremities along with increasing pulse rate is Hypovolemic shock. Hypovolemic shock is due to a critical loss in the effective circulating blood volume with systemic hypoperfusion. If left untreated, hypovolemic shock can lead to ischemic injury of vital organs, leading to multi-system organ failure and death.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Septic shock: This is the last and most severe stage of sepsis. Sepsis occurs when your immune system has an extreme reaction to an infection. The inflammation throughout your body can cause dangerously low blood pressure.

 

Option C. Cardiogenic shock:  Cardiogenic shock takes place when the heart has been damaged so much that it is unable to supply enough blood and oxygen to the organs of the body.

 

Option D. Anaphylactic shock: Anaphylactic shock results from a severe allergic reaction. It causes blood pressure to drop and narrows your airway, making breathing difficult.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypovolemic shock as the most likely type of shock in a child with significant blood loss due to trauma, characterized by symptoms such as cold extremities and tachycardia.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 2720

choices.text: All are correct
B, C, D and E are correct
D and E are correct
Only E is correct

questions.text:
As you are concluding your shift, a junior resident requests you to collect one final arterial blood gas (ABG) sample for the day, hinting at the possibility of metabolic abnormalities, along with elevated osmolality and an increased anion gap. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Distal renal tubular acidosis
  3. Ammonium chloride intake
  4. Urinary tract diversion
  5. Methanol poisoning
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only E is correct

 

Option D:

 

Methanol poisoning is known to cause a high anion gap metabolic acidosis along with increased osmolality due to the accumulation of toxic metabolites like formic acid and formaldehyde. These substances are osmotically active, leading to an increased osmolal gap. The high anion gap results from the excessive production of organic acids during methanol metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Diarrhea: This typically leads to non-anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis due to the loss of bicarbonate in stool rather than an anion gap acidosis. Osmolality is not typically affected to the degree seen in methanol poisoning.

 

B. Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 1 RTA): This condition results in non-anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the kidney's inability to acidify urine. It does not typically cause an increased osmolality or a high anion gap.

 

C. Ammonium Chloride Intake: This can cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis by providing an acid load, but it does not lead to increased osmolality or a high anion gap.

 

D. Urinary Tract Diversion: This can lead to metabolic acidosis due to the absorption of urinary ammonium and chloride ions, but it usually presents as hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis without a significant increase in osmolality or anion gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol poisoning's unique presentation with high anion gap metabolic acidosis and elevated osmolality. Understanding the different causes of metabolic acidosis, including those that affect the anion gap and osmolality, is crucial for diagnosing and managing various metabolic disturbances. Methanol poisoning requires prompt recognition and treatment to prevent severe toxicity and complications.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-83.

choices.text: Tachycardia is a very sensitive indicator of depletion of intravascular volume
Mottling of extremities is seen in early shock
Confusion, stupor and coma are early signs
Respiratory rate is more sensitive than heart rate indicator of early shock

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department, following a road traffic accident. The child was found bleeding and unresponsive at the scene. On examination, the medical team notes pallor, a rapid pulse, and delayed capillary refill. The child's blood pressure is low, and he is not responding to verbal commands. A diagnosis of hypovolemic shock is made, and immediate resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the signs of shock in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tachycardia is a very sensitive indicator of depletion of intravascular volume.

 

Option A:

 

In pediatric patients, tachycardia (an elevated heart rate) is often one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of shock, particularly hypovolemic shock, which occurs due to significant fluid or blood loss. The body compensates for the decreased intravascular volume by increasing the heart rate to maintain cardiac output and perfusion to vital organs. In the context of this child, who has suffered a road traffic accident and is presenting with signs of shock, tachycardia serves as a critical marker of intravascular volume depletion.

 

Hypovolemic shock: Hypovolemic shock in children may have following stages: -

 

i. Early compensated

  • Immediately after hypovolemia, body tries to maintain the BP to maintain adequate perfusion to vital organs through a compensatory mechanisms.
  • An increase in heart rate (Tachycardia) is the earliest and most sensitive indicator for intravascular volume reduction

ii. Late uncompensated

 

If shock state continues or the compensatory mechanisms are not enough to maintain the metabolic needs of the tissue, the shock goes into an uncompensated phase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mottling of extremities is a sign that can be seen in shock but is more indicative of severe or late-stage shock rather than early shock. It reflects poor perfusion and can indicate a progression towards more severe circulatory compromise.

 

Option C. Confusion, stupor, and coma are not early signs of shock; rather, they indicate a more advanced stage of shock, where decreased cerebral perfusion leads to altered mental status.

 

Option D. While the respiratory rate can increase in shock as part of the body's compensatory mechanism to maintain oxygenation and offload carbon dioxide, it is less sensitive than heart rate as an indicator of early shock in children. Tachycardia is generally recognized as a more sensitive and earlier marker of shock than changes in respiratory rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-728.

choices.text: A2 B4 C3 D1
A2 B3 C4 D1
A1 B2 C3 D4
A1 B2 C4 D3

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective radiological changes:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A2 B3 C4 D1

 

Option B:

 

 Splaying (widening of the metaphyses) - This is typically seen in Rickets, where there is defective mineralization or calcification of bones due to vitamin D deficiency, leading to widening and fraying of the metaphysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wimberger’s ring: A classic radiologic sign seen in Scurvy, representing a ring of calcification surrounding an epiphyseal ossification center.

 

Option C. Sclerosis of bones: A characteristic feature of Osteopetrosis, a condition also known as marble bone disease, where the bones become overly dense and structurally abnormal.

 

Option D. Multiple healing fractures: A hallmark of Osteogenesis Imperfecta, a genetic disorder characterized by bones that fracture easily, often with minimal or no apparent cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 1983

choices.text: 10 mL/kg of 10% dextrose
10 mL/kg of 5% dextrose
20 mL/kg of 0.45% normal saline
20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a continuous fever, signs of sepsis, a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, a pulse rate of 144/min, and a respiratory rate of 30/min. Considering the initial management of this child, what is the fluid of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline

 

Explanation:

 

In a septic child presenting with signs of shock, the initial fluid of choice for resuscitation is isotonic saline. A bolus of 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline is recommended to restore circulating volume and improve hemodynamics.

 

Management of Shock in Children

 

  • First step in the management is insertion of two large-bore peripheral IV catheters and prompt administration of crystalloids.
  • Either normal saline or ringer lactate solution is given at 20 mL/kg until perfusion, tachycardia & hypotension resolve
  • If vitals do not improve even after the administration of 60 mL/kg of crystalloid, myocardial dysfunction is likely and inotropes such as dopamine or norepinephrine should be given.
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors (milrinone, amrinone) improve contractility, facilitate diastolic relaxation & decrease SVR.
  • Endogenous vasopressin levels decrease during vasodilatory septic shock & administration of low-dose vasopressin (0.02–0.04 unit/ min) restores SVR
  • Metabolic acidosis & elevated lactate levels occur secondary to tissue hypoperfusion; however, administration of sodium bicarbonate has not been shown to decrease morbidity or mortality.
  • Rather, the base deficit & serum lactate is used to monitor the adequacy of resuscitation.
  • Calcium & potassium ions are integral to conduction & contractility of myocardium & their levels must be monitored & supplemented as needed

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of septic shock in children, emphasizing the use of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) for fluid resuscitation. The goal is to restore circulating volume and improve hemodynamic stability, distinguishing the use of isotonic solutions from dextrose-containing solutions which are more appropriate for correcting hypoglycemia.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-289

questions.text: You are counseling a group of new parents about the nutritional needs of their infants. One parent asks about the daily potassium requirement for their healthy child, who is under 2 years of age and receives a mix of breastfeeding, solid foods, and formula feeding to ensure a balanced intake of vitamins and minerals. Based on the child's dietary regimen, what is the recommended daily potassium intake for this age group?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-2 mEq/kg

 

Explanation:

 

For a healthy child under 2 years of age who is receiving a well-rounded diet including breastfeeding, solid foods, and formula, the recommended daily potassium intake is 1-2 mEq/kg. This range accounts for the potassium needs for normal growth, cellular function, and the maintenance of electrolyte balance and acid-base homeostasis in the body. It is designed to match the intake with the physiological requirements of infants and young children in this age group, considering their rapid growth and development.

 

Educational Objective

 

Recommended dietary requirement of potassium is 1-2 mEq/kg

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition.

choices.text: Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
Giant cell tumor

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a limp and localized leg pain worsening over two months. Examination reveals swelling in the mid-tibia without erythema or warmth. The X-ray finding shows below; and biopsy findings include cells with grooved nuclei, giant cells, and fibroblastic proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

 

Option A:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, X-ray findings of a lytic lesion, and the histological presence of grooved nuclei and giant cells is characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are antigen-presenting cells that can affect various organs, including bone. In the bone, LCH often leads to lytic lesions and can present with localized pain and limping in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Giant cell tumor: This is more common in the epiphyseal region of long bones in young adults, not typically seen in children, and would usually present as a lytic lesion without the characteristic histological findings of LCH.

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma: Typically occurring in the epiphyseal plate of the long bones during childhood and adolescence, but the histological description does not match that of chondroblastoma.

 

Option D. Osteoid osteoma: This benign bone tumor usually presents with nocturnal pain that relieves with NSAIDs and would not show the histological features of LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis can present with a variety of symptoms depending on the organ involved, and when affecting the bone, it can lead to localized pain, swelling, and lesions that appear lytic on X-ray. Recognizing the unique histological features of Langerhans cells is critical for a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 10,626

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to excessive thirst and frequent urination for the past month. The child's physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities except for mild dehydration. Laboratory tests show low serum potassium levels, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bartter syndrome.

 

Option C:

 

The given features of polyuria, polydipsia along with the laboratory features of hypokalemia, hypercalciuria and metabolic alkalosis are suggestive of Bartter syndrome.

BARTTER SYNDROME (AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE)

 

Classic Bartter syndrome:

 

  • Defects—genes that produce the basolateral chloride channel
  • Presents milder in childhood with failure to thrive and a history of recurrent episodes of dehydration.
  • Defect in sodium, chloride and potassium transport in the ascending loop of Henle
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalciuria (similar to chronic loop diuretic use)
  • The loss of sodium and chloride, with resultant volume contraction, stimulates the renin/angiotensin III aldosterone axis.
  • Aldosterone promotes sodium uptake and potassium secretion, exacerbating the hypokalemia.
  • It also stimulates hydrogen ion secretion distally, worsening the metabolic alkalosis. Hypokalemia stimulates prostaglandins, which further activate the renin/angiotensin Il/aldosterone axis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gitelman syndrome will have the features of hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hypocalciuria and hypomagnesemia.

 

Option B. Liddle Syndrome will have the features of hypertension with hypokalemia and suppressed aldosterone

 

Option D. Alport syndrome will have the features of Asymptomatic intermittent microscopic hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bartter syndrome results from defects in the renal tubular function, leading to increased excretion of potassium and chloride, which in turn causes the observed electrolyte imbalances and metabolic disturbances.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 10861
